facts.text: Respondent appointed as pay-clerk in appellants' cash department on April 30, 1945, and confirmed in service with effect from August 1, 1945.
Since beginning of 1949, respondent found negligent, careless, disobedient, and slow in duties; repeated verbal and written warnings given without effect.
Chief Cashier complained by letter dated October 24, 1949, of respondent's negligence, sulkiness, disobedience, shirking duties, and leaving company's money in open drawer without locking.
Respondent submitted written explanation on October 28, 1949, attributing faults to ill health, hard work, mental anxiety; asked to be excused and promised more care.
Chief Cashier complained again on November 17, 1949, of no improvement, gross negligence, absenteeism on flimsy grounds, avoiding duties, insolence.
Charge-sheet issued November 18, 1949; respondent suspended till enquiry disposal.
Respondent wrote to Managing Director on November 19, 1949, pleading not guilty, asking for interview.

Manager investigated, found respondent guilty; respondent admitted rudeness but repentant, apologized; manager recommended one more chance, transfer to Mechanical Engineering Department, warned of termination on further adverse report.
Letter to respondent on November 29, 1949, giving one more chance, transfer to M.E. Department effective next day.
Respondent did not improve; complaints of neglecting work, chatter interfering with typists.
Mr. Hooper gave verbal warnings, then written warning on February 9, 1951, asking for improvement.
Respondent replied February 16, 1951, denying allegations, citing arrears and extra work, admitted occasional talk but not disturbing, asked excuse, promised improvement.
No improvement; complaints of improper work, noisiness, found sleeping twice by Mr. Girling.
Mr. Girling warned on September 3, 1952.
Respondent replied September 8, 1952, denying most, excused sleeping due to illness on doctor's advice, promised satisfaction.
No improvement; letter February 9, 1953, dispensing services but giving another chance, stopping annual increment.
Respondent protested February 17, 1953, charges groundless, asked reconsideration; Labour Directorate refused intervention.
Mr. Hooper to report by May 31, 1953; unless improvement, services terminated June 30, 1953.
Mr. Hooper reported no improvement August 19, 1953.
Final report by Mr. Hooper May 4, 1954.
Letter May 10, 1954: after enquiry, unsuitable, terminate with retrenchment compensation; choose forthwith termination or apply to Tribunal.
No reply from respondent; letter June 21, 1954, approaching Tribunal.
Application to Fifth Industrial Tribunal under s.33 Industrial Disputes Act, 1947 on September 21, 1954; Tribunal functus officio, struck off.
Application under s.22 Industrial Disputes Appellate Tribunal Act, 1950 to Labour Appellate Tribunal due to pending appeal Cal.-152.
Labour Appellate Tribunal heard ex parte October 14, 1955, granted permission, prima facie case made out.
Termination letter November 11, 1955, implementing permission.
Respondent filed affidavit December 6, 1955, for review, set aside ex parte order.
Labour Appellate Tribunal restored application March 6, 1956.
After hearing, Labour Appellate Tribunal rejected application May 11, 1956, no prima facie case.
Special leave to appeal to Supreme Court granted.

legal_issues.text: Whether Labour Appellate Tribunal had jurisdiction to review its ex parte order dated October 14, 1955.
Whether Labour Appellate Tribunal exceeded jurisdiction under s.22 by holding no prima facie case for discharge.
Scope of enquiry under s.22: prima facie case, mala fides, unfair practice, victimization.

petitioner_arguments.text: Labour Appellate Tribunal functus officio after October 14, 1955 order; no jurisdiction to review as not strictly under O.47 r.1 CPC.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Industrial Disputes Appellate Tribunal Act, 1950 s.9; CPC O.47 r.1

petitioner_arguments.text: No prima facie case required for simple discharge simpliciter, only for dismissal; here it was discharge.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Industrial Disputes Appellate Tribunal Act, 1950 s.22(b)

petitioner_arguments.text: Prima facie case made out by history of negligence, warnings, reports; lenient treatment given; no mala fides or victimization.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Atherton West Co. Ltd. v. Suti Mill Mazdoor Union; Automobile Products of India Ltd. v. Rukmaji Bala; Lakshmi Devi Sugar Mills v. Pt. Ram Sarup

petitioner_arguments.text: Termination implemented on November 11, 1955; irrevocable; Tribunal should not have reconsidered.

respondent_arguments.text: Warnings, suspension, stoppage of increment without proper charge-sheet, enquiry, violation of natural justice; arbitrary, victimization.
No prima facie case; denied guilt, attributed to health, arrears, extra work.

court_reasoning.text: Labour Appellate Tribunal has powers of civil court under CPC when hearing appeals; applies to original jurisdiction under s.22; O.41 r.21 CPC applicable for rehearing ex parte order due to non-service of summons.
court_reasoning.key_observation: S.9(1) invests powers as civil court hearing appeal, regardless of original/appellate jurisdiction.

court_reasoning.text: Inherent powers under Tribunal rules analogous to s.151 CPC allow setting aside ex parte order for ends of justice.
Under s.22, Tribunal checks prima facie case, no mala fides/unfair practice; here no formal enquiry, evidence before Tribunal inadequate (no proof of Hooper reports contents, no charge-sheet).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Prima facie case not proved even if evidence believed; lacuna in evidence.

court_reasoning.text: No distinction for discharge vs dismissal here, as appellant sought dismissal for guilt.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Appellant's own case was for dismissal.

court_reasoning.text: Post-termination implementation irrelevant; appeal concerns only correctness of May 11, 1956 order.
Tribunal found no unfair practice/victimization, but no prima facie case; decision correct.

holdings.text: Labour Appellate Tribunal had jurisdiction to review and rehear ex parte application under s.22.
No prima facie case made out for permission to discharge; Tribunal correctly refused permission.
Tribunal's enquiry under s.22 limited to prima facie case, mala fides etc.; evidence must enable possible conclusion if believed.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal, upholding Labour Appellate Tribunal's order dated May 11, 1956, refusing permission under s.22 to discharge the respondent, as no prima facie case was made out and Tribunal had jurisdiction to review ex parte order.

key_quotes.text: The Tribunal before whom an application is made under that section has not to adjudicate upon any industrial dispute... but has only got to consider whether the ban... should be lifted. A prima facie case has to be made out by the employer...
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Defines scope of s.22 enquiry from Lakshmi Devi Sugar Mills

key_quotes.text: A prima facie case does not mean a case proved to the hilt but a case which can be said to be established if the evidence which is led in support of the same were believed.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains standard for prima facie case

key_quotes.text: While determining whether a prima facie case had been made out the relevant consideration is whether on the evidence led it was possible to arrive at the conclusion in question and not whether that was the only conclusion which could be arrived at on that evidence.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Tribunal assesses possible view, not substitutes judgment
